title: LaVern Dilweg
text:
LaVern Ralph "Lavvie" Dilweg (November 1, 1903 – January 2, 1968) was a professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> player, <a href="Lawyer">attorney</a>, and <a href="United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives">U.S. Congressman</a> from <a href="Wisconsin">Wisconsin</a>.
Football.
Born and raised in <a href="Milwaukee">Milwaukee</a>, Dilweg attended its public schools and graduated from <a href="Washington%20High%20School%20%28Milwaukee%29">Washington High School</a>. He enrolled at <a href="Marquette%20University">Marquette University</a> in Milwaukee and played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> for the <a href="Marquette%20Golden%20Avalanche%20football">Golden Avalanche</a> under head coach <a href="Frank%20Murray%20%28coach%29">Frank Murray</a>. A three-sport college athlete, he played <a href="Center%20%28basketball%29">center</a> on the <a href="Marquette%20Golden%20Eagles%20men%27s%20basketball">basketball</a> team and was a <a href="shot%20put">shot put</a>ter on the <a href="Track%20and%20field">track</a> team. Dilweg was an <a href="College%20Football%20All-America%20Team">All-American</a> <a href="End%20%28gridiron%20football%29">end</a>, and played in the first <a href="East%E2%80%93West%20Shrine%20Game">East–West Shrine Game</a> in <a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a> in late 1925. The Golden Avalanche had a record of 28–4–1 during Dilweg's four years.
After two undergraduate years at Marquette, Dilweg had enrolled in the <a href="Marquette%20University%20Law%20School">MU law school</a>, and was admitted to the Wisconsin Bar in 1927. While in law school in <a href="1926%20Milwaukee%20Badgers%20season">1926</a>, he played professionally for the <a href="Milwaukee%20Badgers">Milwaukee Badgers</a>, an <a href="National%20Football%20League">NFL</a> team in its fifth year that folded before the end of the season. While practicing law in <a href="Green%20Bay%2C%20Wisconsin">Green Bay</a>, he continued to play pro football, he signed with the <a href="Green%20Bay%20Packers">Green Bay Packers</a> in August <a href="1927%20Green%20Bay%20Packers%20season">1927</a> and played through the <a href="1934%20Green%20Bay%20Packers%20season">1934</a> season, with football in the morning and afternoons at the law office. Dilweg was recognized as one of the best ends in the NFL during the late 1920s and early 1930s and the Packers won three consecutive <a href="List%20of%20NFL%20champions">NFL championships</a> in <a href="1929%20NFL%20season">1929</a>, <a href="1930%20NFL%20season">1930</a>, and <a href="1931%20NFL%20season">1931</a>. Dilweg was a <a href="Official%20%28American%20football%29">football official</a> in the <a href="Big%20Ten%20Conference">Big Ten Conference</a> until his move to <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> in early 1943.
Dilweg played in 107 games (out of a possible total of 113) while starting 72 of them. Records are incomplete, but they show Dilweg having 12 touchdowns with 23 receptions on 443 yards. Considered the best all-around end in pro football prior to <a href="Don%20Hutson">Don Hutson</a>, Dilweg was named to the NFL 1920s All-Decade Team, and is only one of two players on the list not in the <a href="Pro%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Pro Football Hall of Fame</a>. He was named consensus All-Pro for five consecutive years, with four of those years being unanimous All-Pro. In 2005, he was named to the <a href="Professional%20Football%20Researchers%20Association">Professional Football Researchers Association</a> Hall of Very Good in the association's second HOVG class and his candidacy for induction into the Professional Football Hall of Fame is one of four candidacies that the PFRA officially supports.
Political career.
During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, Dilweg was elected to <a href="United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives">Congress</a> in <a href="United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives%20elections%2C%201942%23Wisconsin">1942</a> as a <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrat</a> from the <a href="Wisconsin%27s%208th%20congressional%20district">8th district</a>. He announced his <a href="Candidate">candidacy</a> in late July, less than four months before the election, and defeated incumbent <a href="Joshua%20L.%20Johns">Joshua Johns</a>. He served in the <a href="78th%20United%20States%20Congress">78th United States Congress</a> (January 3, 1943 – January 3, 1945), but was not re-elected in <a href="United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives%20elections%2C%201944%23Wisconsin">1944</a>, defeated by <a href="John%20W.%20Byrnes">John Byrnes</a>, who went on to serve 28 years in the seat. Dilweg resumed the practice of law in Green Bay and Washington, and was confirmed as a member of the <a href="Foreign%20Claims%20Settlement%20Commission">Foreign Claims Settlement Commission</a> in 1961, appointed by President <a href="John%20F.%20Kennedy">Kennedy</a>.
Death.
Ill for several months after surgery, Dilweg was on vacation with his wife in <a href="Florida">Florida</a> in early 1968 when he died in <a href="St.%20Petersburg%2C%20Florida">St. Petersburg</a>, where they had been visiting friends. His death came just two days after the famous <a href="1967%20NFL%20Championship%20Game">Ice Bowl</a> game at Green Bay on New Year's Eve. Dilweg is interred at the Fort Howard Cemetery in Green Bay.
Personal.
Dilweg's wife, <a href="Eleanor%20Coleman">Eleanor Coleman Dilweg</a> (1906–1978) was an <a href="Swimming%20at%20the%201924%20Summer%20Olympics">Olympic</a> swimmer from Milwaukee and a former world record holder. They met at Marquette, married in 1927, and had three sons. Son <a href="Gary%20T.%20Dilweg">Gary</a> (b. 1937) graduated from the <a href="United%20States%20Naval%20Academy">U.S. Naval Academy</a> and served in the <a href="United%20States%20Marine%20Corps">U.S. Marines</a>, and later in the <a href="Wisconsin%20Legislature">Wisconsin legislature</a> as a <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> from Green Bay.
Grandson <a href="Anthony%20Dilweg">Anthony Dilweg</a> was an NFL quarterback from 1989 to 1991, with the Packers and <a href="1991%20Los%20Angeles%20Raiders%20season">Los Angeles Raiders</a>. He played college football at <a href="Duke%20Blue%20Devils%20football">Duke</a> under head coach <a href="Steve%20Spurrier">Steve Spurrier</a>.
